Glycerol carbonation with CO2 and La2O2CO3/ZnO catalysts prepared by two different methods: Preferred reaction route depending on crystalline structure Chan-yi Park Huy Nguyen-Phu Eun Woo Shin ⁎ School of Chemical Engineering, University of Ulsan, 93 Daehak-ro, Nam-gu, Ulsan 44610, South Korea School of Chemical Engineering University of Ulsan 93 Daehak-ro Nam-gu Ulsan 44610 South Korea ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract La2O2CO3/ZnO catalysts for glycerol carbonation with CO2 to produce glycerol carbonate were prepared by two different methods – co-precipitation (conventional method) and ethylene glycol combustion (novel method) – and investigated their catalytic properties and performance through characterization and reaction tests. La2O2CO3/ZnO prepared by the novel method (NLZ) showed higher yields of glycerol carbonate than La2O2CO3/ZnO prepared by the conventional method (CLZ) due to extremely high selectivity of glycerol carbonate by NLZ, even though NLZ exhibited lower glycerol conversions. Depending on the preparation method, predominant La2O2CO3 phases were different: monoclinic La2O2CO3 for NLZ and hexagonal La2O2CO3 for CLZ. From characterization of the spent catalysts, zinc glycerolate, an intermediate in this reaction, was formed in a large aggregate of nanoparticles over the spent CLZ, while the spent NLZ contained a trace amount of zinc glycerolate. These different catalytic behaviors were explained on the basis of catalytic reaction routes and La2O2CO3 structures. Keywords Glycerol carbonate Carbon dioxide La oxycarbonate ZnO Preparation method 1 Introduction The focus on biodiesel as a renewable, clean energy source brought about a rapid increase in its worldwide production. Simultaneously, glycerol was also increasingly produced as a by-product at a rate of 10% of biodiesel production, resulting in a surplus over traditional requirements in the chemical industry [1–4]. Consequently, it is necessary to develop new applications for low-cost glycerol in commercial applications. Glycerol can be applied to the synthesis of various value-added fine chemicals such as acrolein, 1,3-propanediol, polyglycerols, and glycerol carbonate (GC) [5–8]. GC has been considered a versatile fine chemical for many potential applications. It is widely used as an adhesive and surfactant as well as a component in gas separation membranes and paints. It can also serve as a useful solvent in lithium-ion batteries and as a source of polymers such as polyesters, polycarbonates, polyurethanes, polyamides, and lubricating oils [9–11]. GC can be synthesized from glycerol via different reaction routes. At present, the direct carbonation of glycerol with CO2 as well as the indirect catalytic transesterification with carbonates or urea have received much attention as environmentally friendly reaction routes for GC synthesis [12,13]. GC has been synthesized by the transesterification of glycerol with dimethyl carbonate [1,14–17]. However, carbonates such as dimethyl and diethyl carbonates for the transesterification reaction would be relatively expensive chemicals, leading to less commercial benefit. GC synthesis by glycerolysis of urea has been performed over various catalysts [2,6,18–22]. In this process, ammonia is produced as a by-product, which necessitates low-pressure reaction conditions to remove the ammonia gas. The direct synthesis of GC by carbonation of glycerol with CO2 was introduced as a green process in which two cheap raw reactants – glycerol, a by-product of biodiesel production, and CO2, a green house gas – can be converted to a value-added chemical, GC [23–26]. The synthesis of GC from glycerol and supercritical CO2 has been conducted with zeolites and basic ion-exchange resins as catalysts [23], and the direct reaction of glycerol with CO2 was also studied over tin complexes, CeO2–Al2O3 or CeO2–Nb2O5, showing low conversions of glycerol because of thermodynamic limitations [24–26]. Recently, in order to overcome these limitations, an attempt to use acetonitrile as a coupling agent in the synthesis of glycerol carbonate from glycerol and CO2 was carried out [3,9]. La-Zn mixed oxide materials, prepared by a co-precipitation method as a catalyst for the reaction, showed GC yields over 10% in test reactions. The high catalytic activity of La-Zn catalysts was rationalized as a synergism between La and Zn and the formation of La2O2CO3, resulting in an increase in ZnO dispersion and improvement of glycerol activation. However, there was no further explanation of how the La2O2CO3 structure influenced catalytic performance in the reaction. In this work, La2O2CO3/ZnO catalysts for direct glycerol carbonation with CO2 were prepared by two different methods: co-precipitation (conventional method) and ethylene glycol solution combustion (novel method). The catalytic behavior and properties were compared through FE-SEM, HR-TEM, FT-IR, XRD, N2 adsorption/desorption, and reaction tests. The novel preparation method for La2O2CO3/ZnO catalysts was first used for macroporous perovskite-type complex oxide catalysts of La1–xKxCo1–yFeyO3 for diesel soot combustion [27]. The catalysts prepared by the novel method (NLZ) in this study contained a disordered macroporous structure and an abundant monoclinic La2O2CO3 phase over the La2O2CO3/ZnO mixed oxide materials, which were different characteristics compared to catalysts prepared by co-precipitation (CLZ). In the reaction results, NLZ catalysts showed better catalytic behavior of high selectivity and yield of GC, which were explained by a proposed scheme for the reaction routes and differences in the La2O2CO3 crystalline structures as determined by characterization of the fresh and spent catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Conventional La2O2CO3/ZnO catalysts were prepared via a typical co-precipitation method. Zn(NO3)2·6H2O and La(NO3)3·9H2O were first mixed with a prepared 2M NaOH solution to form a salt solution that was added dropwise to 50ml of deionized water with sufficient stirring at a constant pH of 11. After aging at 60°C for 3h, the obtained precipitate was filtered and washed with deionized water to remove remaining sodium ions. The precipitates were dried at 80°C for 12h, followed by calcination at 500°C in the air for 5h. These catalysts were designated as CLZ-x, where x represents the relative atomic ratio of La and Zn. In this study, in order to enhance the properties of the catalysts, we employed another method, ethylene glycol combustion [27]. Novel La2O2CO3/ZnO catalysts were prepared by combustion of ethylene glycol and methanol solution using Zn(NO3)2·6H2O and La(NO3)3·9H2O as starting materials. Mixed lanthanum and zinc nitrates were dissolved in ethylene glycol with stirring at room temperature for 2h. After thorough mixing, methanol was added in moderate amounts to obtain a sufficient concentration. The ethylene glycol-methanol mixed metal nitrate solution was heated in a furnace at a rate of 1°C/min from room temperature to 550°C and was kept at this temperature for 5h. The catalysts were designated as NLZ-x, where x represents the relative atomic ratio of La and Zn. 2.2 Characterizations of catalysts The surface areas and pore size distributions of the catalysts were characterized by the nitrogen adsorption-desorption technique (Micromeritics ASAP 2020, USA). The samples were measured at −196°C using an automatic analyzer. The surface morphologies of the catalysts were observed by field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM-EDX, JEOL, JSM-600F, Japan) with an energy dispersive spectrometer. High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM) images were obtained using a JEOL JEM-2100F (JEOL, Japan). Samples were prepared by suspending and grinding in an ethanol solution, and two drops of ethanol solution containing the ground catalyst powder were placed on a carbon film-coated copper grid. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were measured on a Rigaku D/MAX-2200 powder X-ray diffractometer (Rigaku Corporation, Japan) using a Cu Kα radiation source (λ=0.15418nm). The X-ray tube was operated at 35kV and 20mA. The two theta angle was scanned from 10–90° (step wise 0.02o) at a speed of 2o/min. The XPowder software program was employed for indexing XRD peaks and calculating the phase fractions from XRD patterns. Weight losses in fresh and spent catalysts were determined by a thermogravimetric analyzer (TA Instruments Q50, USA). Approximately 20mg of catalyst was charged into a sample pan and heated to 1000°C at a rate of 3°C/min under a stream of air. CO2 temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) experiments were conducted in a quartz flow reactor (BELCAT-M, MicrotracBEL, Japan). The calcined catalysts were heated from room temperature to 950°C (15°C/min). The desorption gas (10vol% CO2/He) was fed into the reactor at a flow rate of 30ml/min. Infrared spectra of the samples were measured in the form of KBr powder-pressed pellets on a Nicolet 380 Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectrophotometer (Thermo Electron Co., USA) under ambient conditions. Spectra were recorded by co-adding 124 scans at a resolution of 4cm−1 over a spectral range from 400–4000cm−1. 2.3 Reaction tests For analysis, 0.1mol of glycerol (9.2553g) was placed into a 50ml stainless-steel autoclave equipped with an impeller. At the same time, 0.4605g of prepared catalyst and 20.12ml of CH3CN were added to the reactor. CO2 was then introduced into the autoclave at an initial pressure of 4.0MPa at room temperature. The reactor was heated to 170°C and kept at that temperature for 12h under magnetic stirring in order to allow the catalytic reaction. After the reaction, the autoclave was cooled to room temperature, and excess CO2 was slowly vented by N2 purging. For quantitative analysis, tetraethylene glycol was employed as an external standard. Considering the low solubility of glycerol and its products in tetraethylene glycol and their high solubility in ethanol, a certain amount of ethanol was also added for dilution of the reaction mixtures. Samples were analyzed on a capillary column SHIMADZU CBP/20 (25m×0.22mm) in a gas chromatograph equipped with a flame ionization detector. In order to calculate the numerical values of the reaction results, calibration curves of GC and glycerol were used in an external standard method. Conversion, selectivity, and yield were calculated by the following equations. The BET surface areas of CLZ-0.25 and CLZ-1 catalysts were 18.6 and 48.9m2/g, respectively, which are similar to the values reported in a previous study [8]. For the NLZ catalysts, the BET values were 30.4 and 11.4m2/g, respectively, which are also consistent with literature values [27]. Fig. 1 shows N2 adsorption–desorption isotherm plots of the catalysts. The NLZ catalysts belong to a type II isotherm according to the IUPAC classification and present a hysteresis loop, where the low-pressure portion of the near linear middle section implies that the sample is macroporous (Fig. 1c and d) [27–29]. However, the hysteresis loop around high p/p0 in the isotherms indicates the presence of mesopores within the macropore wall, resulting in dual porosity of NLZ catalysts, which is in good agreement with literature observations [27]. FE-SEM images of each sample are shown in Fig. 2 . The morphologies of the catalysts were totally different depending on the preparation method. The co-precipitation method for CLZ catalysts generates aggregates of nanoparticles (Fig. 2a and b), whereas the NLZ catalysts have a disordered honeycomb-like macroporous structure (Fig. 2c and d) resulting from the release of a large amount of gas produced by the low-temperature oxidation of ethylene glycol to glyoxylate dianion in aqueous solution and the thermal decomposition of metal glyoxylates during the preparation. In the case of NLZ catalysts, FE-SEM images clearly confirmed development of disordered macroporosity, which is consistent with the results of N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm analysis. Elemental mapping results of Zn and La in NLZ-0.25 are displayed in Fig. S1 (see Supplementary materials), indicating that Zn and La were well distributed throughout the catalyst. Fig. 3 shows XRD patterns of the fresh catalysts. First, the typical XRD patterns of white zincite ZnO with a P63 mc space group (JCPDS 36-1451) were collected at 2θ=31.8°, 34.4°, 36.3°, 47.5°, 56.6°, and 62.9° for all of the catalysts. The peaks of ZnO in CLZ catalysts appeared much sharper than those in NLZ catalysts, indicating high crystallinity of ZnO in the CLZ catalysts. The Scherrer equation was employed to calculate the crystallite sizes of ZnO for all of the catalysts. The ZnO crystallite sizes of CLZ-0.25 and CLZ-1 were 30.1 and 34.9nm, respectively, reflecting the high crystallinity of the ZnO phase, while the values of NLZ catalysts were 6.6 and 7.6nm, corresponding to broad peaks in the XRD patterns. In summary, all of the catalysts contain ZnO phases whose crystallite sizes over NLZ catalysts were much smaller than those over CLZ catalysts. La oxycarbonate is a polymeric complex constructed of slabs forming a layer-type structure of La2O2 2+ and CO3 2− ions [30–32]. Three different crystalline structures (type I, Ia, and II) can form according to the location of La2O2 2+ ions in the complex [31]. Type I of La oxycarbonate were square layers of La2O2 2+ ions in a tetragonal crystalline form separated by CO3 2− ions. Type Ia was the monoclinic distortion of type I, representing monoclinic La oxycarbonate. Type II was a hexagonal crystalline structure of La oxycarbonate [32]. In Fig. 3, characteristic XRD peaks for La-oxycarbonate (La2O2CO3) are also observed. The type of La-oxycarbonate over the catalysts depends on the preparation method. In the case of NLZ catalysts, monoclinic La2O2CO3, P63/mmc space group (JCPDS 48-1113) was the main La oxycarbonate phase whose characteristic peaks appeared at 2θ=13.1°, 22.8°, 26.7°, 29.5° and 44.4°. In contrast, CLZ catalysts contained hexagonal La2O2CO3 structure with a P63/m(176) space group (JCPDS 37-0804), indicated by XRD peaks at 2θ=20.1°, 25.3°, 25.9°, and 30.4°. La2O2CO3 phase fractions (hexagonal La2O2CO3/monoclinic La2O2CO3) on each catalyst are calculated using the XPowder program for quantitative comparison (Table 1). The phase fraction values clearly show the dominant La2O2CO3 phase over the catalysts: the hexagonal La2O2CO3 phase for CLZ catalysts with high values of 3.14 and 2.67 and the monoclinic La2O2CO3 phase for NLZ catalysts with low values of 0.13 and 0.06. With an increasing La/Zn ratio, the intensity of the characteristic peaks for La2O2CO3 phases was proportionally increased in both types of catalysts. Meanwhile, the Scherrer equation was also used to calculate the crystalline sizes of both La-carbonate forms. The crystallite sizes of hexagonal La2O2CO3 in CLZ catalysts were around 20nm, while those of monoclinic La2O2CO3 in NLZ catalysts were ca. 10nm. The data for crystalline particle sizes are listed in Table 1. The La oxycarbonate structures were also investigated via FT-IR analysis [31–34]. FT-IR spectra of the fresh catalysts were monitored and are plotted in Fig. 4 . Several modes as typical FT-IR bands for La oxycarbonate are assigned (Table 2 ). With the CLZ catalysts, CO3 2− vibrations appearing at 745, 855, 1066, and 1518cm−1 correspond to type II hexagonal La oxycarbonate. In the case of NLZ catalysts, bands representing type Ia monoclinic La oxycarbonate appear around 845 and 1367cm−1. The bands around 845cm−1 show three-fold splitting due to more than one CO3 2− type [31–34]. The band at 1367cm−1 is also assigned as a characteristic peak for monoclinic La oxycarbonate [30,31,34]. Therefore, FT-IR analysis confirmed the predominant existence of type Ia monoclinic La oxycarbonate over NLZ catalysts. Fig. 5 shows CO2-TPD profiles of the fresh catalysts. CO2-TPD was used to evaluate the strength and amount of basic sites including oxygen species and hydroxyl groups accepting protons serving as Bronsted base sites [34–37]. In the literature, CO2 adsorption onto La2O3 can be categorized into two adsorption sites: i) surface basic sites from which CO2 desorbs below the pretreatment or calcination temperature and ii) bulk basic sites where adsorbed CO2 forms structural La oxycarbonates that can be decomposed above the calcination temperature [34,37]. Correspondingly, in Fig. 5, weak and broad peaks below 500°C can be assigned to CO2 desorbing from surface basic sites, whereas strong peaks above 600°C represent CO2 decomposed from the bulk structure of La oxycarbonates. The peak patterns of CO2 desorbing from the surface basic sites are similar for all of the catalysts. However, the intensities of the latter peaks of NLZ-1 and CLZ-1 were much higher than those of NLZ-0.25 and CLZ-0.25, indicating an increase in the relative amounts of La oxycarbonates in the catalysts. Additionally, TGA and DTG profiles of the fresh catalysts were monitored (Fig. 6 ). Similar to the CO2-TPD profiles, the TGA patterns can be divided into two regions – below and above 500°C. Below 500°C, there were regular, small weight losses originating from diverse unknown sources. A relatively sharp drop in weight% appeared around 600–650°C, which can be assigned to CO2 gas decomposed from bulk La oxycarbonate structures [38]. The DTG profiles of the fresh catalysts were also dependent on the content of La oxycarbonate and not on the preparation method. The catalysts containing more La oxycarbonate (NLZ-1 and CLZ-1) clearly show sharp peaks at 660°C, demonstrating release of CO2 from the La oxycarbonate structure. This result is in good agreement with the CO2-TPD data. 3.2 Catalytic tests The reaction results for glycerol carbonation with CO2 are listed in Table 3 . NLZ catalysts produced higher GC yields (10.4% for NLZ-0.25 and 14.4% for NLZ-1) than CLZ catalysts (8.9% for CLZ-0.25 and 9.1% for CLZ-1). In terms of TOF, NLZ catalysts exhibited better catalytic performance with values of 1.55×10−4 for NLZ-0.25 and 1.63×10−4 for NLZ-1. Interestingly, the higher GC yields for NLZ catalysts were achieved due to the remarkably high selectivity of GC (49.3% for NLZ-0.25 and 59.2% for NLZ-1), i.e., NLZ catalysts showed much higher GC selectivity even with lower glycerol conversion than CLZ catalysts. According to previous studies [3,9], the reaction pathways for glycerol conversion to GC over La2O2CO3/ZnO catalysts are mainly composed of two steps on each solid phase (Scheme 1 ). Glycerol can first be converted to zinc glycerolate (ZnGly) and water as a result of reaction with the ZnO phase (step 1). Subsequently, GC can be produced by CO2 insertion into ZnGly over the La2O2CO3 phase (step 2). Accordingly, in Table 3, the high glycerol conversion and low GC selectivity of CLZ catalysts would be strongly related to the generation of ZnGly, implying a high amount of ZnGly over the spent CLZ catalysts. In contrast, NLZ catalysts show much high GC selectivity with low glycerol conversion, implying that a small amount of ZnGly is generated over the spent NLZ catalysts because ZnGly is a short-lived intermediate in the pathway of glycerol to GC with respect to the reaction kinetics for glycerol conversion. The much higher selectivity of GC over NLZ catalysts clearly indicates that the reaction from ZnGly to GC (step 2) would be much preferred. Conversely, the low GC selectivity with high glycerol conversion over CLZ catalysts indicates inhibition of the reaction in step 2, resulting in a large amount of solid ZnGly in the spent catalyst. This unique catalytic behavior over NLZ catalysts is closely related to their different catalytic properties compared to those of CLZ catalysts. 3.3 Characterization of spent catalysts In order to further understand the catalytic behavior, the spent catalysts were characterized by XRD, FT-IR, TGA, and FE-SEM. Fig. 7 shows XRD patterns of the spent catalysts. In the case of CLZ catalysts, new strong peaks appearing at 2θ=10.9°, 17.2°, 20.7°, and 27.6° are assigned to the crystal phase of ZnGly with a space group P21 /c (JCPDS card No. 00-23-1975). The sharp and intense XRD peaks of ZnGly indicate the formation of well-crystallized ZnGly during the reaction (Fig. 7 a and b). In contrast to the high crystallinity of ZnGly, there are much smaller characteristic peaks for ZnO at 2θ=31.8°, 34.4°, and 36.3°, compared to the fresh CLZ catalysts. Sharp and strong characteristic peaks for the ZnO phase in the fresh CLZ catalysts decrease rapidly in the XRD patterns of the spent CLZ catalysts, irrespective of the large crystallite sizes of ZnO nanoparticles. These data suggest that, under the reaction conditions in this study, the ZnO phase in the fresh CLZ catalysts is readily transformed to ZnGly crystallites via step 1 in Scheme 1. However, with NLZ catalysts, totally different behavior was observed in the XRD patterns of the spent catalysts. In Figs. 7c and d, there is no characteristic XRD peak for ZnGly, implying no formation of ZnGly crystallites over NLZ catalysts. This observation is in good agreement with the aforementioned reaction results that CLZ catalysts have relatively high glycerol conversion and low GC selectivity, while NLZ catalysts show the opposite trend. According to the reaction pathways in Scheme 1, ZnGly is an intermediate in the pathway from glycerol to GC, i.e., ZnGly is a product in the reaction between ZnO and glycerol and is a reactant for the reaction of ZnGly and CO2 (step 2). The sharp and strong XRD peaks of ZnGly over CLZ catalysts and the absence of XRD peaks over NLZ catalysts clearly reflect the preference of each catalyst to the relative reaction rates in step 1 and step 2. In addition, the Scherrer equation was again employed to measure the crystallite sizes of each phase in the spent catalysts, and the results are listed in Table 4 . The crystallite sizes formed over CLZ catalysts were 96.9 and 102.3nm, respectively, whereas there was no formation of ZnGly over NLZ catalysts. In the case of ZnO crystallite sizes, the spent catalysts of both types contained a larger ZnO phase than the fresh catalysts. In particular, the ZnO crystallite sizes of NLZ catalysts were 29.1 and 25.5nm, respectively, much larger than the ca. 7nm of ZnO crystallite for the fresh NLZ catalysts. The sharp peaks of the ZnO phase in the XRD patterns of the spent NLZ catalysts (Fig. 7c and d) reflect agglomeration of the ZnO phase during the reaction. Characteristic peaks for monoclinic La oxycarbonates in the XRD patterns of the spent NLZ catalysts were clearly observed at 2θ=13.1°, 22.8°, 26.7°, 29.5°, and 44.4° (JCPDS 48-1113). The XRD peak intensities of the spent catalysts were relatively increased after the reaction compared to those of the fresh NLZ catalysts. Additionally, the crystallite sizes of monoclinic La oxycarbonate over NLZ catalysts increased from 9.3 and 10.7nm to 18.8 and 19.4nm after the reaction, respectively (Table 4). In the case of the hexagonal La oxycarbonate phase over CLZ catalysts, the crystallite sizes in the fresh catalyst (21.4 and 20.8nm) and spent catalysts (24.8 and 23.9nm) were similar. Therefore, the XRD patterns of La oxycarbonate in the spent catalysts indicate that the hexagonal La oxycarbonate phase of the fresh catalysts does not change during the reaction, while the monoclinic La oxycarbonate over NLZ catalysts agglomerates due to involvement in reaction step 2 (Scheme 1). The FT-IR spectra of the spent catalysts are shown in Fig. 8 . First, it is apparent that characteristic bands for ZnGly appear at 1123, 1942, 2842, and 2881cm−1 in both types of spent catalyst, indicating the existence of a solid ZnGly phase in all of the spent catalysts. The band at 1123cm−1 corresponds to CO stretching related to alcohol in ZnGly, bands at 2842 and 2881cm−1 are from CH stretching, and the band at 1942cm−1 comes from CO stretching where the oxygen is involved in a hydrogen bond [38,39]. Therefore, all of the spent catalysts contain functional groups of the ZnGly solid phase formed through the reaction of ZnO with glycerol in reaction step 1. Second, depending on the preparation method, the intensities of bands related to ZnGly were clearly different even with the same amounts of ZnO phase in the fresh catalysts. The spent CLZ catalysts showed a much higher intensity of functional groups from ZnGly than the spent NLZ catalysts, which results from the production of greater amounts of ZnGly over the spent CLZ catalysts. This is a reasonable result since, over CLZ catalysts, reaction step 1 where ZnGly is produced from ZnO and glycerol is preferred, and reaction step 2 where ZnGly converts to GC and regenerates ZnO is inhibited, which is in good agreement with XRD measurements. However, in contrast to the XRD results, functional groups of ZnGly were observed even in the FT-IR spectra of NLZ catalysts. The relatively low intensity of ZnGly functional groups in the FR-IR spectra and the absence of ZnGly crystallite in the XRD patterns imply the existence of very small amounts of ZnGly over the spent NLZ catalysts. From this observation, we infer that the relatively fast reaction in step 2 over NLZ catalysts retains a much smaller amount of ZnGly in the spent catalysts since ZnGly readily reacts to yield GC and ZnO. The TGA and DTG profiles of the spent catalysts were monitored to quantitatively measure the amount of ZnGly in the spent catalysts (Fig. 9 ). The FT-IR and XRD analyses of the spent catalysts showed that ZnGly and La oxycarbonates were the main solid components that can be decomposed in the TGA profiles. In Fig. 9B, there are two major decomposition peaks: a sharp peak around 360°C corresponding to decomposition of ZnGly into ZnO and a broad peak above 600°C assigned as the release of CO2 from the La oxycarbonate structure. In the case of NLZ catalysts, the TGA and DTG profiles of the spent catalysts were very similar to those of the fresh catalysts (Fig. S2, See Supplementary material). The weight loss above 600°C in the spent NLZ catalysts is proportional to the amount of La oxycarbonate in fresh NLZ catalysts. From these TGA, XRD, and FT-IR results, we conclude that a negligible amount of ZnGly is formed over NLZ catalysts during the reaction, and its functional groups can only be detected in FT-IR spectra. In contrast, the TGA and DTG profiles of the spent CLZ catalysts show a sharp drop around 360°C, which is caused by the decomposition of ZnGly [40]. The weight losses below 500°C for CLZ-0.25 and CLZ-1 were 24% and 32%, respectively, implying that the spent CLZ-1 contains a greater amount of ZnGly. The weight losses by decomposition of La oxycarbonate above 600°C for CLZ-0.25 and CLZ-1 were 6% and 2.5%, respectively, which is opposite the amounts of La oxycarbonate in the fresh CLZ catalysts. Thus, the higher generation of ZnGly over CLZ-1 causes smaller La oxycarbonate content in the spent catalysts. HR-TEM images for fresh/spent CLZ-1 and NLZ-1 catalysts were collected (Fig. 10 ). Enlarged TEM images and the corresponding FFT patterns of each crystalline component are displayed. For fresh CLZ-1, hexagonal La2O2CO3 and ZnO nanoparticles were detected, while fresh NLZ-1 contained monoclinic La2O2CO3 and ZnO nanoparticles, as shown in the TEM image and SAED patterns (Figs. S3–4, see the Supplementary material). In the case of spent CLZ-1, as expected, the ZnGly structure was also clearly monitored with hexagonal La2O2CO3 and ZnO nanoparticles, confirming the formation of ZnGly via reaction step 1 over CLZ catalysts (Fig. 11 ). FE-SEM images of the spent catalysts, shown in Fig. S5 (see the Supplementary material), were obtained to confirm the change in morphology of the catalysts. Even though spent CLZ catalysts retained the shape of aggregated nanoparticles, the sizes of the nanoparticles became much smaller compared to the fresh catalysts. The morphology of NLZ catalysts also maintained their disordered macroporous structure, but similarly, the thickness of the macroporous frames became very thin after the reaction. The transformation of ZnO into ZnGly during reaction step 1 was responsible for the change in catalyst morphology after the reaction. 3.4 Schematic view of the reaction routes and their relationships with crystalline structures In Scheme 1, the reaction routes over the catalysts for GC production are divided into two parts: step 1 over ZnO phase and step 2 over La2O2CO3 phase. The solid ZnO phase is involved in step 1 to produce ZnGly, which reacts with CO2 over the La2O2CO3 phase to generate GC and ZnO (step 2). In the reaction results (Table 3), CLZ catalysts show higher glycerol conversion and much lower GC selectivity than NLZ catalysts, indicating that a large amount of ZnGly can be produced in the spent CLZ catalysts since the reaction rate in step 1 is much faster than in step 2 over CLZ catalysts. Conversely, the relatively faster reaction rate in step 2 over NLZ catalysts minimizes the amount of ZnGly in the spent NLZ catalysts. This expectation is well supported by the characterization data of the spent catalysts. XRD, FT-IR, and TGA analyses confirm that ZnGly crystalline particles were formed over the spent CLZ catalysts. In contrast, over the spent NLZ catalysts, ZnGly was not detected in XRD and TGA measurements, and only vibration modes of functional groups of ZnGly were observed in the FT-IR spectra, which implies that the ZnGly formed in step 1 is readily converted back to ZnO over the monoclinic La2O2CO3 phase. Based on these findings, we propose schematic structures of the fresh and spent catalysts in Scheme 2 . As the curved graphical arrows and their sizes reflect the reaction steps and rates, respectively, the dominant reaction steps and the generated amounts of ZnGly are directly influenced by the La2O2CO3 phase structures (Scheme 2). The difference in catalytic behavior over CLZ and NLZ catalysts is closely related to their bulk and surface properties. From the characterizations, there are two remarkable unique properties of NLZ catalysts: disordered macroporosity and monoclinic La2O2CO3 phases. The influence of the former on the catalytic reaction routes is unclear; however, the latter can be considered a key variable for catalytic efficiency [34,41]. Ni et al. investigated the effect of the crystal structure of Mg-La mixed oxide-supported Ni catalysts in the dry reforming of methane [41]. They found that, with increasing Mg/La mole ratio, hexagonal La2O2CO3 in the bulk phase was enriched, indicating a lack of monoclinic La2O2CO3 phase. According to their explanation, the lack of surface monoclinic La2O2CO3 deactivated the catalyst due to fast carbon formation since monoclinic La2O2CO3 species were responsible for adsorption of CO2 and carbon removal in the reaction. Moreover, the unique selectivity of La-based nanoparticles for CO2 was investigated by X-ray absorption and emission spectroscopy [41]. One finding in the literature was that the Ln2O2 2+ layer in the monoclinic La2O2CO3 phase contained pyramidal-oriented oxygens with a Ln atom in the middle, whereas the same layer in the hexagonal La2O2CO3 phase consisted of distorted LaO8 coordinated rhombohedra, indicating fewer neighboring oxygen atoms of La in the monoclinic La2O2CO3 phase than in the hexagonal La2O2CO3 phase. Therefore, the difference in La2O2CO3 crystalline structures may sufficiently induce the unique catalytic behavior over NLZ catalysts in this study: high reactivity of monoclinic La2O2CO3 crystalline structure for the reaction step 2 where adsorbed CO2 is inserted into the ZnGly structure. As shown in Scheme 2, the monoclinic La2O2CO3 crystalline structure facilitates the faster rate of ZnGly reacting with CO2. 4 Conclusions In this study, La2O2CO3/ZnO catalysts for glycerol carbonation with CO2 were prepared through two different methods: conventional co-precipitation (CLZ) and a novel ethylene glycol combustion method (NLZ). NLZ catalysts showed a higher GC yield than CLZ catalysts. The catalytic behaviors of the catalysts were totally different: lower glycerol conversion and higher GC selectivity over NLZ catalysts and opposite results over CLZ catalysts. Based on characterization of the fresh and spent catalysts, the unique structure over NLZ catalysts with a monoclinic La2O2CO3 crystalline structure would be preferred for the reaction in step 2 where ZnGly, an intermediate in the reaction, reacts with CO2 to produce GC and ZnO. Characterization of the spent catalysts by XRD, FT-IR, TGA, and HR-TEM provided clear evidence of the formation of highly crystalline ZnGly nanoparticles over the spent CLZ catalysts. coredata.dc:description: La2O2CO3/ZnO catalysts for glycerol carbonation with CO2 to produce glycerol carbonate were prepared by two different methods – co-precipitation (conventional method) and ethylene glycol combustion (novel method) – and investigated their catalytic properties and performance through characterization and reaction tests. La2O2CO3/ZnO prepared by the novel method (NLZ) showed higher yields of glycerol carbonate than La2O2CO3/ZnO prepared by the conventional method (CLZ) due to extremely high selectivity of glycerol carbonate by NLZ, even though NLZ exhibited lower glycerol conversions. Depending on the preparation method, predominant La2O2CO3 phases were different: monoclinic La2O2CO3 for NLZ and hexagonal La2O2CO3 for CLZ. From characterization of the spent catalysts, zinc glycerolate, an intermediate in this reaction, was formed in a large aggregate of nanoparticles over the spent CLZ, while the spent NLZ contained a trace amount of zinc glycerolate. These different catalytic behaviors were explained on the basis of catalytic reaction routes and La2O2CO3 structures.
coredata.dc:title: Glycerol carbonation with CO2 and La2O2CO3/ZnO catalysts prepared by two different methods: Preferred reaction route depending on crystalline structure
